docs.snippet: Wasn’t this election supposed to be a nail-biter? Recent character moments and poll numbers suggest that President Obama is ahead....
docs.lead_paragraph: Wasn’t this election supposed to be a nail-biter? Recent character moments and poll numbers suggest that President Obama is ahead.
docs.abstract: Charles M Blow column contends that consistent poll numbers, and a string of gaffes by Mitt Romney, indicate that Pres Obama's chances for re-election seem bright; notes that Obama's lead is particularly promising in a number of key battleground states.

docs.snippet: Jobs and inequality should be the issues....
docs.lead_paragraph: I learned much of what I know about the political economy of the Second Gilded Age from Tom Edsall. Writing for Campaign Stops, Edsall has some important things to say about how economic narratives will play next year. He argues that the polling data
docs.abstract: Jobs and inequality should be the issues.

docs.abstract: With McCain's support rising, the Democratic candidate has his work cut out for him at the convention.

docs.snippet: Senator Barack  Obama captured  Wisconsin by a comfortable margin, winning with voters in every age group except people older than  65. Those voters split their support between Mr. Obama and Senator John  McCain, according to exit polls.     Repub...
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama captured Wisconsin by a comfortable margin, winning with voters in every age group except people older than 65. Those voters split their support between Mr. Obama and Senator John McCain, according to exit polls. Republicans fought unsuccessfully to pick up a Congressional seat in the conservative-leaning Eighth District, the only competitive House race in the state. In a rematch of the race from two years ago, John Gard, a former State Assembly speaker, lost to Representative Steven Kagen, a Democrat.
docs.abstract: Wisconsin Democratic Rep Steven Kagen wins re-election over Republican John Gard; Republican incumbent F James Sensenbrenner defeats Independent Robert Raymond; Democrat Ron Kind beats field that includes Kevin Barrett; Barack Obama wins state; 56-43 percent; tally (S)

docs.snippet: Barack Obama may owe his narrow win in Indiana to good old-fashioned get-out-the-vote work. Exit polls show that nearly a quarter of voters questioned said they had been contacted by the Obama campaign about coming out to vote, compared with 8 per...
docs.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama may owe his narrow win in Indiana to good old-fashioned get-out-the-vote work. Exit polls show that nearly a quarter of voters questioned said they had been contacted by the Obama campaign about coming out to vote, compared with 8 percent for the McCain campaign. Of those contacted as part of the Obama effort, almost three-quarters said they voted for him. The Libertarian candidate, Bob Barr, was another major factor. With all but a handful of election districts counted, Mr. Obama held a lead over Mr. McCain of just 26,163 votes, less than 1 percent of the votes cast. Mr. Barr received 29,186 votes.
docs.abstract: Indiana Gov Mitch Daniels defeats Democratic challenger Jill Long Thompson; Barack Obama wins state, 50-49 percent; tallies (S)

docs.snippet: The state where Senator Barack Obama was born and spent most of his youth easily went his way and two Democrats, Neil Abercrombie and Mazie K. Hirono, coasted to re-election to the House of Representatives.     Democrats also claimed three seats i...
docs.lead_paragraph: The state where Senator Barack Obama was born and spent most of his youth easily went his way and two Democrats, Neil Abercrombie and Mazie K. Hirono, coasted to re-election to the House of Representatives. Democrats also claimed three seats in the State Legislature, expanding their control to all but 8 of the 76 seats.
docs.abstract: Democratic Reps Neil Abercrombie and Mazie K Hirono are easily re-elected to Congress in Hawaii; in heated race for mayor of Honululu, Mufi Hannimann defeats Ann Kobayashi; Barack Obama wins state, 72-27 percent; tallies (S)

docs.snippet: The president’s older daughter apparently disregarded her parents’ counsel that she need not choose a school with a big name and reputation....
docs.lead_paragraph: The president’s older daughter apparently disregarded her parents’ counsel that she need not choose a school with a big name and reputation.
docs.abstract: White House Letter; Malia Obama chooses to attend college at Harvard, following children of many previous presidents and world leaders, despite her father's insistence that elite colleges are not necessarily best option; will take gap year and enroll in 2017, after Pres Obama has left office.

headline.main: Malia Obama Rebels, Sort of, by Choosing Harvard
headline.print_headline: A First Daughter Rebels, Sort of, by Choosing Harvard

byline.original: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and NICHOLAS FANDOS
